Posted: December 20, 2013
												This is one of the better games available these days.  The variety of difficulty choices means that you can choose anywhere from a casual gaming experience to a fairly challenging one.  Its new game plus feature adds to this, increasing the available content to include more challenging dungeons and quests, and pushing the potential difficulty as far as one is willing to take it.There are a wide variety of items, and options for customizing them through enchanting or socketing ember so that you can build your character as you see fit. There are also a host of unique items, including class specific ones that tailor to the differing aspects of the different classes.Aside from different classes being available, each class has three sets of skills to choose from, allowing different kinds of playstyles. For example, one could make a tank-like Engineer, or, one could make a cannon-wielding ranged attacker as an engineer.Adding to the variety of class options, the multiplayer opens up new possible playstyles, allowing players to synergize their skills with other players.  Through teamwork, certain tasks that may have previously been too challenging alone as a particular build may be able to be conquered with help from others.And finally, beyond the basic storyline gameplay, there is the "map" system, allowing one to visit endless multitudes of dungeon types in the spirit of the original Torchlight.  These dungeons can be generated using special maps which can be purchased in the game, allowing one to choose what kind of dungeon, what level range it is, and what special effects are enabled, such as enemies dropping more money, enemies being more powerful, certain elements dealing extra damage, among other possibilities.  So for the people who like to play a game into the ground, Torchlight II definitely is a good candidate for sinking time into.It's not without its flaws, of course, but there's nothing game-shattering.  Load times can be a little long between new areas at times.  Depending on the difficulty one has chosen, some enemies may be able to instantly kill the player with certain attacks(much like Diablo II enemies on the Hell difficulty).  Also, it's difficult to tell exactly what a skill will do, or how useful it will be, until you've had the opportunity to play around with it. There is a skill reset system to help deal with this, but you can only reset the last 3 skill points you have spent.  There is very little else wrong with it aside from those problems.Finally, the possibilities from mods allow you to change basically anything, even the player limit for multiplayer.  There's not much to say about this, but it's still a major feature of the game.  If you enjoy modding your games, Torchlight II is a fine candidate.I highly recommend Torchlight II to everyone.  It's easily a 9/10, one could play this game for hundreds of hours per class, or more.  Hardcore mode, new game plus, random dungeons, gear progression...Lots of replay value.

												I have always really enjoyed dungeon-crawling RPG's (diablo and the like) and so I am also a very harsh critic of them. To that point, I HATED Torchlight 1, but I am actually a big fan of Torchlight 2. More so than Diablo 3 (pre-Reaper of souls) and more so than dungeon siege 3.This game really did impress me though. The action is fast-paced and quite consistent as well. Gone is Torchlight 1's horrible scheme of 100 levels of same-dungeon-different-layout; now the game plays in more of an open world, where there are connected regions which have various side dungeons (and 'side-quests') within them. You can fill it all in and search for better drops or you can just move foward with the main questline if you like. I am also quite fond of the skill and ability systems. It is very reminiscent of Diablo 2, more so than the third. You can select which character stats to increase, as well as which skills to level up. You don't really have a skill 'tree' as you are free to select them at your own whim. However, there are 'ranks' for each skill which give you a bonus trait or added effects once you hit certain levels with each ability.All in all this game can be very addicting. The visuals and text can be a little too cartoon-y for my taste, but it is very easy to lose track of time while combing a new map or thrashing your way through a dungeon and it is fun to take the (short amount of) time to build your character. Plus there's multiplayer, so fun with a friend!

Posted: October 17, 2014
												Happy about the great success of Torchlight, Torchlight 2 was made and a good competitor to the failed release of Diablo 3.Almost looking like the first game, they tried to change a lot that went wrong in the first game:The classes:Babarian (melee), Outlander (ranged), Embermage (caster), Engineer (dafuq???)The story:The alchemist (playable character from the first game) went crazy from the presence of the evil overlord they killed in the first game and starts to lay waste on the world, searching for a cure.On your way you will encounter 4 villages and 4 different areas, with countless dungeons and open regions. Unlike the first game, it is not a continuing endless dungeon, but a world, with regions and borders. The dungeons are still random generated, but no longer endless.Every major region you will encounter several bossfights and events.First being let down by the beta, I tried the game again and saw, that they changed most of the issues that made it from the first into the second game:- Attributes are now more easy to understand and you always know now, what you are skilling for- Skilltrees are more logical and you can mix easily abilitys (and more important passives) like you want- Skills and classes are more balanced, no class is an alone ranger anymoreThe endless dungeon is replaced by the map systems, similar to the maps from the first game, where you activate a random short dungeon. Now, every dungeon has a endboss, and every map has prefixes, like + loot or + damage.Also it has a New Game+ function, where you can restart the campaign on a higher level. You can do that several times until you are at the max enemy level of 105 and your own level of 100.The problem again is, that you can powergame again with abilitys, that use % of weapon damage. While most abilitys have a fixed damage, those will scale with your weapon and can make insane amounts of bonus damage, outranging all other abilitys. Big looser again, is the Mage with nearly none % abilitys. Big winner is the engineer, that literally can clear the whole screen with one attack.Having full steam workshop mod support, the game is customizable and fun for longer playing.(I dont recommend it for achievment hunters, because several achievments are bugged and locked)

Posted: January 19, 2013
												In torch light two you play the decendent of the shoot girl from torch light one (The one that was supposed to be going around lighting the torches).  Your predecesor has failed in her mission to light the four torches of light, mostly in part because she was unable to find any unlit torches, and now you have to continue in her foot steps to light all of the torches.  Twice.  The idea is that the player will travel across azer..ember town, lighting magical torches, extinguishing them, and then lighting them again.  This task is all but impossible as there are no torches to light.  At this point I believe this isn't a glitch, as I believed with the first game, as it's been a few years and it seems like it would be kind of a huge oversight to forget about it twice in a row.  The sequel has made several improvements however, including the ability to press "1" and say "Time to die!", as well as having all references to internet "ME ME's" removed.  In all honesty I've only played this game for an hour, and I already like it more than another certain game which will be left un named.  However, if it was not to be left un named it would be named "Diablo 3" which is pretty much the best example of how NOT to make a game like Torchlight 2.

Posted: October 10, 2012
												Runic returns with their second chance at Diablo 2(.5). It definitely meets all my expectations, and the developers certainly deserve all the compliments they're receiving from fans. However, I think there's still a lot that Torchlight 2 can bring to the table. For example, I would really like to see some more polish on the targeting system. My character being unable to tell the difference between attacking and running away (even when clicking off to the far edge of the screen) is a definite step backwards. Also, though not the most important part of a game, the art-style of the cutscenes were not my favourite thing ever. I suppose it was better than the first game, and something is better than nothing. Additionally, I must commend them on not shying away from storytelling. Actually, some of my favourite parts in the game were the little stories scattered through the sidequests (like the werewolves and journal entries in Act 3).

												Crowborn's Review of Torchlight II-Ever since I was a boy, and got my hands on Diablo 1, I have been a fan of the hack-n-slash game-genre. Something about the game strung a cord inside of me, and I played it almost non-stop for years. Same with the sequel - it kept me busy through highschool and sane in the awkward years following when I was rampaging through life, trying to figure out what the 'eck I wanted to do. And so arrived the highly anticipated 3rd installment of the Diablo genre - to lackluster reviews. I picked it up immediately of course, but I were never able to enjoy it. It just seemed off to me, seemed strange, like an orange growing on an apple-tree, trying to fit in with the smooth green skinned fellas around it. But for me it failed at the deceit, and I put down the game after playing it for only a few months. Dissapointed and bereft of one of my favourite genres, I started looking around for substitutes. That's when I heard about Torchlight II.I had noticed the series before, but for some reason never gotten around to trying it out. It was supposed to be a fairly good diablo-clone, and while I liked the genre, it wasn't until one of my dear steam-friends gifted me the game, that I actually managed to sit down and play it. I felt obliged to, so to say. And my were I pleasantly surprised!Torchlight II is a really well made game. From the steam-punkish world, cross the interesting skill-sets, to the actio-packed maps - this game just breathes fun game design. Granted, the game is 'very' much a Diablo-clone, and anyone who ever played those games will immediately find everything intimately familiar. But that's not a bad thing. In fact, I find it darned good. I didn't have to read a bible of game-guides before daring to venture out in the the world of Torchlight, and hack and slash my way through the first pack of monsters I came across. It granted me immediate satisfaction and loads of fun.It feels to me like the devs of this game did right, what the guys at Blizz did wrong. Torchlight II follows to a point the tried and true old recipe of hack-n-slash. They don't try to reinvent or alter the genre, but instead stick to what works and 'has' worked for the last two decades. You got your attribute-points, your skill-points, random loot, runes and enchantments to upgrade your gear, rewarding exploration, and a story-line that doesn't distract you from your dungeon-delving fun.The game hearkens back to the good old days, and gives the players exactly what they expected - and a little more. It deserves a top grade, but due to an at times non-transparent stat-system and unbalanced characters, I have to subtract a few points. I give it:8.5/10

Posted: July 4, 2014
												This is perhaps one of the best point-and-click fantasy RPG games I have had the pleasure of playing. Not only are there different difficulties and online, a massive selection of pets, multiplayer servers that host up to six players at a time, but the story line and characters are highly interesting.There are four classes to choose from, a mage, an engineer, a gun-slinger, and the classic bezerker. Each has their own special trait that makes each unique and desirable to different types of players. Choosing a class doesn't limit you to their stereotypical equipment, though! Being a dual axe-weilding Embermage and being questioned about  why  I use axes instead of a staff or wand is just a portion of the fun!I am what I presume to be about one-third of the way through the game judging by level and achievement progress, though I intend to continue playing after I complete the game with my current character. Perhaps the biggest problem I'm facing is my pet hawk being so much more powerful than me. then again, I suppose I am the one that taught it such powerful spells and provided stat-boosting equipment in the form of a collar and tags.One of my most recent side quests had me help a man recover masks in an attempt to bring peace to two warring races, and though I won't spoil all the details, it was a perfect, "Plot twist!!!" moment that had me grin and facepalm at my want to help (And need for xp!)  He turned out to be evil and needed the masks to gain power. Whoopsies! Was fun defeating him though~ Overall, I would suggest this game to anyone that enjoys RPG-style games that finds others hard to run due to system requirements. The minor issues I experience are not enough to subtract from the experience and pleasure of this game. A 9.5/10

												Holy Smokes,I knew this game was gonna be good, but it far surpassed my expectations. I've spent around 20 hours so far on this game just looking for treasure. The pets feel like companions, not just second inventories, they help you fight and you can even teach them spells (my hawk can summon skeletons and shoot fireballs). It also has fulfilling side quests and achievments. There are also many references to other games and movies; so far I've come across what I believe to be a Minecraft reference and a reference to Monty Python and the Holy Grail. Bottomline this is a great game that's enjoyable in both single player mode and co-op mode; it has plenty to offer and for a ridiculously low price for what it's worth.Highly Recommended

												Enough of the Diablo 2 comparisons - the genre has evolved enough to......wait....ha ha who the hell am I kidding. Torchlight 2 is something like Antje Traue; it's silently risen to the apex of its genre (or in Traue's case, she's climbed over the plastic American bimbos from Hollywood and has become the most attractive woman in the universe). I was never too interested in the first TL game, but this was mostly because I was ingesting too much morphine and I had a serious porn addiction. What immediately grabbed me about its sequel, however, was its foundation in the Steamworks system. It's so simple to download and install mods, and while it's technically limited to ten active at any one time, it's quite easy to combine mods in the GUTS editor. As of the end of 2013, I really have no idea why any developer wouldn't want this implemented in their gaming environment. It extends playability by an infinite margin, and the only excuse I could think of from "big-time" publishers is that they really couldn't give a♥♥♥♥♥♥if people play their game - they only care about sales. (Insert TORtanic joke here.) But okay, enough soapboxing. Is it worth buying? If you're even remotely intrigued by the isometric hack-n-slash model, this game is a godsend (remark about religion). It's visceral, bloody, fast-paced, and there are so many different ways to play. I don't remember how many vanilla classes there are, but if you get off your soggy♥♥♥♥♥for two seconds you can find about twenty new classes in the workshop. There is so much to offer in this package, and you should buy it. 10/10 would play again

Posted: January 17, 2016
												I stayed away from TL2 for a long time, fearing that it'd be nothing more than a mindless hack and slash.  In ways that's exactly what it is - it's been called 'what Diablo III should have been', but there is some strategy here.  The choices you make in how to equip your character do matter, and the game itself is enjoyable.There's no sandbox world here, though so far it seems large enough.  Basic gameplay consists of undertaking quests with your hardy pet companion, beating the snot out of whoever gets in your way, stealing their loot and getting rewarded for it.  Overall you're chasing after a bad guy called the 'Alchemist' who I'll assume wants to do bad guy things.  I haven't played Torchlight, which makes me feel like I'm missing a little something of the plot - but not enough to affect my enjoyment of the game.Your pet....is awesome, and probably one of the best companions/allies I've ever had in any RPG ever.  I chose a cat, and he just wades into the thick of the melee.  In the demo version I gave him a spell and he sat back with me fireballing everything that looked at us funny.  Sometimes in battles I'd have to stand back to let my hit points recover.  My cat would literally claw his way out, tearing a hole through the enemies and I swear give me a look that said 'wuss.'Don't expect meaningful plot choices or a hundred subplots (though there are side missions.)  That said, if you want to kill some stress by wading into an army of ratlings/skeletons/spiders/politicians and coming out bloodied but unbowed, this game's for you.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												Torchlight II is cheap, fun, and addicting what's not to love about that?+ Beautiful Visuals: Torchlight II probably offers one of the most broad color palettes of any game ever with maybe the exception of Borderlands 2, the visuals are simple yet beautiful and stand apart from most other games in their own way.+ Wonderful loot system: Being a huge fan of ARPGs (Diablo in particular) I can't help but love any game mechanic that showers me with items whenever I make something explode, this is a game that makes you work hard for those hard to find items but when you finally get them it makes it all worth it.+ Multiplayer: The multiplayer in Torchlight is wonderful and features a drop in drop out system so regardless of what level or what part of the campaign you're playing you can join your friends at any time. The game's single player is fun so throw in three buddies (Seven friends with a mod) and it's a blast a little hectic but still alot of fun.+ Accessable difficulty: I personally hate games being overly difficult that's just my personal opinion, I don't play games to be frustrated I play games to have fun so I was quite pleased when I found out that Torchlight has multiple difficulties ranging all the way from easy to rediculous there's something for everyone.+ System requirements: PC has a TON of great games, running all of them is a different story and the variety of great games with low system requirements grows smaller by the day it's nice that a game that is as much fun as Torchlight is can be enjoyed by pretty much anyone with a PC.+ Mods: Since it's release Steam has opened the Steam Workshop to it which has infinitely expanded it's gameplay it's options at this point are rather limitless.- Visually messy multiplayer: I personally don't have this problem but I've read about people complaining that multiplayer becomes visually 'messy' with multiple players so it's something to keep in mind if you're buying this to play with other people.- Sometimes loot drops feel slightly disproportionate: Sometimes it feels like loot drops from average enemies are just as lucrative as boss loot drops.- Story is pretty weak: Not that Torchlight is known for it's outstanding story but yeah it's pretty weak here.Torchlight is a wonderful bargain and overall an enjoyable experience that I suggest everyone try at least once.8.5/10Reasonable Price Point: This game has been a bargain since day one and it has a wonderful development team I would say at least $30 USD.

Posted: April 4, 2013
												I would like to preface this by noting that I have not played Torchlight 1. Due to the fairly close release dates, comparisons to Diablo 3 are inevitable.Torchlight 2 is basically Diablo 2 with more kiddy/cartoony 3D graphics. The game uses a fairly similar skill tree system to D2. For better or worse, investing points become permanent, so you'd best be committed to a build. Fortunately there are some mods that enable one to redo choices without triggering the cheating flag, but it's still something I'd rather avoid altogether. Meanwhile Diablo 3 allows you to 'respec' at will, which to be honest, is quite nice.I dabbled in all the classes, but I mostly played the Engineer and the Archmage. The class balance isn't too bad, but on higher difficulty levels, I'm not sure how one is expected to survive as a melee character. I even tried pure Vitality builds, and monsters still whack you down fast. In D3 melee characters are surprisingly sturdy.Leveling speed is pretty good. Every time I start a character it feels like I'm blowing through levels. Even in D3 with an exp gem in the helm, a Hellfire Ring and 10 Monster Power, leveling doesn't feel as fast as T2.Multiplayer T2 has been... iffy. Even months after release, I found desyncs happen, even with their servers being far less crowded. Somehow Diablo 3 manages to be playable despite all the nonsense that goes on the screen.I'm sad that Torchlight 2 had very little story. I was expecting this grand quest of discovery, only to be met with staple busy work. The quests were largely "kill monster, get reward." Heck, I already forgot what the game was about. Even if it's not the point of the game, I'd still like more compelling reasons to play.When you reach the end, you get to play New Game Plus, which mainly just ups the level of game and you retain everything. To be honest, this did not interest me at all. D3's approach is to go with an extra 100 bonus character levels, which also is not appealing.The verdict? If you had to choose I'd have to say Diablo 3 is the superior game, especially if you can get it on one of their 50% off sales. D3 offers more classes, considerably more spells, better graphics, sound, story, even replay. Biggest downsides are the 10 character limit and permanent online status.

Posted: December 10, 2015
												Coming from somebody that did play Diablo 2 back in the day (and wasn't as fond of it as other people), this game takes the typical frustrating aspects of that game and throws them out the window. While it's possible that Diablo 3 does some of these things as well, I'm afraid I haven't played that game yet. First, you can load up your pet with unwanted loot and send it back to town while in the middle of a dungeon to sell for you. Generally returning after two minutes. You can even have it purchase stuff in town for you, like potions or scrolls. It's so nice to not have to constantly port back to town to empty out my inventory. You also don't have to click on gold to pick it up. You just have to walk over it. I may never play Diablo 2 again after getting used to such a nice feature. You get a hotbar for skills. You don't even need to have potions take up space on it because pressing Z or X automatically uses your best healing or mana potion. So I can press 1 for a firestorm, press 2 for fire pillars, press 3 to summon a ghost, etc. It kinda feels like playing an MMO. You can find ambiguous spells on any character that you can have four of equiped at any time, offering some variety into your gameplay. Like a spell that summons a horde of zombies, or a simple fireball, or a passive buff to your EXP and gold earned. The really cool part is that your pet also gets four spell slots and will use any spells automatically when you get into a fight and they're off cooldown. I have my pet set to summon two hordes of zombies AND some skeleton archers, with a passive spell that increases his damage and shortens the time it takes for him to get back from town. There's so much this game does right that it makes me kinda disappointed that the devs have moved on to other projects and don't plan to update Torchlight 2 anymore. But still, the game has easy intigration built in for the modding community. Totally recommended.

Posted: December 3, 2012
												best diablo cloneEdit: Since recommendations have apparently been converted into reviews I thought I should elaborate a bit.First off: TL2 is not as good as Diablo 2. After playing it for a bit again, 70 hours or so, I tried D2 again and the better gameplay and design choices just felt really immediate. I went on to go for Patriarch again. That said TL2 is the best of the "clones" I've played. It's not worthy as a successor but as with some other genres it seems that the pioneer will always remain the greatest.Regarding graphics. At their best, the graphics look fantastic. TL2 in 60 FPS is really something that must be seen to be believed. Unfortunately the graphics are unusually heavy, and most computers will find it hard to keep the framerate high, especially in big battles. Said big kerfuffles also bring to light another problem regarding the visuals. They're very busy. So busy in fact, that in the multiplayer each player has a column of blue light emanating from them so that you can identify players in the mess. This is not a good thing, relatively I say that D2 still has better graphics, not because they're flashy with advanced effects, but because they're concise and serve the gameplay. Freeze, poison, curses and auras, other important spells etc. are easy to identify in D2, in TL2 not so much. The overabundance of various effects and the subtlety of others makes the graphics not serve gameplay so well.Thematically, TL2 is obviously a big deviator when it comes to comparing to D2. If you can get over it, the visual design is occasionally pretty stunning. However at times it feels somewhat generic, as "cartoony á la WoW" has become the go-to fantasy style over the past ten years or so.  The gameplay is a mixed bag. The skill system is simpler than D2's all across the board, but the attributes are done differently. One of the usual complaints in D2 is that other than the mandatory Strength and Dexterity points, all points for all characters go in Vitality. In TL2 all attributes are useful for every character in some fashion, but optimal distribution is usually just stacking Strength or Focus, as those are the attributes that increase damage by a percentage. Vitality is not as useful as in D2, as the HP increase is not as important and because the other bonus granted from it is block and armor increase, which tends to be useful for shielded characters only. Dexterity gives minor things like critical change, dodge and fumble recovery. Fumble is another mechanic new to TL2, instead of missing, characters can Fumble their autoattacks which makes them cause reduced damage. The reason for this seems to be making the combat feel more satisfying, as characters missing with attacks is a common complaint with action RPGs. However it usually seems to just make it more frustrating, at least for me, as Fumble just makes it look like your character just barely scratches the enemies with his autoattacks, with no clear reason, as fumbled attacks look the same as normal ones. The constant fumbling combined with relatively powerful active skills makes builds involving large amounts of auto-attack rare and/or not that useful. In comparison to D2, most every melee attack utilized auto-attack attack speeds, life leech, etc. but in TL2 very few of those kinds of bonuses apply to the active skills. And because the actives do much more damage and other things, relying on auto-attack and utilizing the bonuses for it is seldom a sensible option. Regarding skills, as mentioned, the system is not as robust as Diablo 2's. Skills are divided into three "trees", but you don't need to invest in prerequisites, so they're more like categories instead of trees. There are no synergies, so builds come down to using skills that work well with each other, or just spamming the most overpowered skill possible, like the Engineer's Emberquake. The skill scaling is different: instead of diminishing returns like D2, TL2 goes with flat increases every rank, as in rank 1: 9% dodge, rank 2: 12% dodge, rank 3: 15% dodge, etc. This is a double-edged sword. On one hand skill increases stay meaningful all the way to the end. Some skills in D2 hit diminishing returns hard which meant that there wasn't really a point in spending more than a few points in certain skills. On the other hand, especially at the start, the skill increases feel petty and unimportant. For instance: would you rather spend another point in the skill to gain 2% more damage, or buy a new skill altogether that does good damage with just one point in it, and even scales (a new feature in TL2)?Scaling is another point. Most skills scale in damage with level, generally with skills that do flat amounts of damage instead of weapon damage. Weapon damage is another problem in itself. A disproportionally large amount of skills rely on weapon damage, even the Embermage's and Outlander's more spell-like abilities. In addition to it not making much sense, it also makes your weapon, and its DPS to be more precise, overly important. Some builds in D2 relied more on weapons, and usually it was regarded as a weakness. In TL2 most builds need weapon damage which makes the DPS the focal point of gear. The other bonuses aren't that important, especially considering that several weapon enchantments only activate on autoattacks, like mentioned. Gear as a whole is not nearly as well thought out as in D2. Because it's the only real source for HP, most every item choice on Veteran and beyond is decided by the amount of health on the item. In D2, most characters got plenty of health from Vitality, and life on gear was relatively rare, so it wasn't that important. In TL2 you MUST stack health to stand a chance on the harder difficulties. This combined with the underwhelming bonuses of the other usual enchantments meas that itemization is  banal and pointless. Adding to this problem is the fact that most uniques have boring, nonsensical or otherwise worthless bonuses that make them unique only in the sense that you'd have to be a real hipster to ever equip them, most of the time. Their drop rate is overly high too, and some bosses even drop guaranteed uniques, most notably the last boss which always drops two. Sets are done a little differently. Set is more like an enchantment instead of an item rarity, and two of the same set item can be worn and it will still count towards completion. This makes them much more common and more viable for non-twinks, but causes them to lose their uniqueness quite a bit. The aforementioed health stacking is also a limiting factor regarding sets, as some just don't want to spawn with HP on them.The inclusion of multiplayer was something that was highly anticipated. Unfortunately it works in about the same manner as Open Battle.net in D2, which makes it pretty worthless for anything serious. There are rudimentary anti-cheating features in place but with local saves anything resembling ladders or an economy is just a futile effort. Another pretty big blunder is the unbelievable amount of player separation. D2 had realms, ladder and non-ladder and hardcore and softcore. TL2 has Casual, Normal, Veteran, Elite, NG, NG+, NG++, etc., hardcore and softcore, so maybe you see my point. The player base gets splintered into so many sections that it really hurts the ability to play with others. So mainly the multiplayer is only good for playing with friends. Also, the loot is instanced, depending on point of view this is a good or a bad thing.It might seem like I'm complaining about everything but I feel like I'm just scratching the surface, but my point is that it's not as good as Diablo 2, but an OK clone on its own, and fun for its own reasons. Recommended if you want to play solo or with a friend for a bit for fun, but not if you're looking for the next greatest aRPG/dungeon crawler/hack'n'slash/click looter/diablo clone/whatever. For that we have D2 still.

												Torchlight picks up the story where it left off as some new BBEG arises, and looks totally amazing. I hope he's better than the final boss from the first game.... Anyway.Impossibly better than the first, for once, the only things that changed for the better, is everything. They fixed the inventory system by providing three seperate tabs that automatically sort loot when you add it to your inv. This, in turn, means a much bigger inv system (3x bigger to be exact) and is all-in-all a needed and welcome change.Graphics are graphics and while they are improved, honestly it still could've looked like the first and I'd be cool with it. They changed the loot system so now the naMES OF THE WEAPONS APPEAR ABOVE THEM AND YOU'RE ABLE TO CLICK THEM AND PICK THEM UP THAT WAY.You cannot understand how much of good change this is. Oh my goodness I'd pick up the same weapon billions of times to pick up the one I actually wanted once. Its changes like that, small but simple ones. Like how in Pokemon now, you can just sit there and keep healing your pokemon with many potions at once where before you were taken back to your backpack. Such a waste of time. Not anymore.There are tons of pets to choose some, some sillier than others. I still went with the wolf because dog. There are a few other types of dogs (like, humorously, the papillion. Just....why.) There are also more classes to choose from, like the classics: embermage, knight, and 'outlander'. But there are a few new ones I didn't go for like some type of Engineer type thing. I dunno.New loot, new weapons, the hand cannon is very very fun to use. I was sad to not be able to summon clouds of minions to do my bidding but eh.I also was confused to find the buttons to access the inv were in different places. Style choice sure but couldn'tve you kept them where they were? Either way.If you enjoyed Torchlight like I did, this is a real rise to glory, and is more of the same, so get clicking.10/10/10/10/10/10/10

Posted: July 15, 2013
												Torchlight 2 is a Loot-Driven Action Roleplaying Game, very similar to the legendary Diablo franchise.It's also very fitting that some of the people that developed it are some of the old Diablo devs and even the soundtrack is made by the same person that did the soundtrack to Diablo series.The gameplay is pretty standard, click on the enemies, they die, you get loot, rinse and repeat until you level up and spec your points into stats and skills. Basically it's just like any other "Diablo-like". You choose from one of 4 classes, which can use any type of weapon and armor in the game, excluding some legendary/unique class specific items. Even though you only have 4 classes, they can be build into several diferent roles. For example, an Outlander can be your standard "Ranger" type class or you can spec it to be a summoner or a even crititcal dealing assasin. You also have tons of variety when it comes to items, as the monsters and chests are very generous into sharing it with you.The game looks gorgeous, not due to any "HD 4K Textures" or some nifty effects like "HBAO+" and "Sunshafts", the game has none of that. What it does have are some nice simple textures and an awesome visual style. The game runs great on both low end PC/Laptops, to the very high end SLI/Crossfire machines.In addition to all of that, the game's community is still very active to this day and thanks to the mod tools provided by the devs, the game has plenty of mods to choose from.In general, it plays great, it looks great and it performs great. If you like games such as Diablo, Titan Quest, Path of Exile and Sacred, you'll love Torchlight II.

												You can't talk about Torchlight 2 without talking about Diablo 3, and I can't talk about Diablo 3 without feeling morose and amused. Blizzard have developed a lot of my favourite video games, though they are not the developer that I once loved. Diablo 3's release was a joke and shows the folly of imposing always online in a game that does not need it. I find it worrying that Blizzard, Activion Blizzard now I suppose, are helping set this precedent of very heavy handed DRM.Torchlight 2 is fun, cheap, can be played in offline mode and has a lan mode. I like that hoarding ember has been discouraged in the game and I like all of the classes. It was pretty silly that I had to use autohotkey in Torchlight as key bindings for abilities could not be changed but thankfully this is different in Torchlight 2. Mod support has vastly increased the life of the game for me. I've not even progressed past the second area as I've spent so much time playing around with community created classes and such in hardcore mode.I'd reccommend purchasing and playing this video game, especially when it is on sale for <£10.

												Another Diablo clone, most people who haven''t actually played the game might say, but once you play it, you can know how polished the game is, it was created by ex-diablo II developers, and it improves on diablo II in a number of ways. The skill tree is now varied and you are not forced to go a specific path. Weapons are not soft limited to a single class, although some specific weapons and items still exists. For those who like D2, they will like TL2, and the surprising feeling is that once we played the game, we don't get the feeling that it is another D2 clone. With a good levelling up system that doesn't require much character grinding, TL2 delivers on what D2 was missing all along. With huge community support, tons of mods and customization, map packs once you finish the main quest, it will keep you enjoyed for long hours.

Posted: June 24, 2014
												I have always really enjoyed dungeon-crawling RPG's (diablo and the like) and so I am also a very harsh critic of them. To that point, I HATED Torchlight 1, but I am actually a big fan of Torchlight 2. More so than Diablo 3 (pre-Reaper of souls) and more so than dungeon siege 3.This game really did impress me though. The action is fast-paced and quite consistent as well. Gone is Torchlight 1's horrible scheme of 100 levels of same-dungeon-different-layout; now the game plays in more of an open world, where there are connected regions which have various side dungeons (and 'side-quests') within them. You can fill it all in and search for better drops or you can just move foward with the main questline if you like. I am also quite fond of the skill and ability systems. It is very reminiscent of Diablo 2, more so than the third. You can select which character stats to increase, as well as which skills to level up. You don't really have a skill 'tree' as you are free to select them at your own whim. However, there are 'ranks' for each skill which give you a bonus trait or added effects once you hit certain levels with each ability.All in all this game can be very addicting. The visuals and text can be a little too cartoon-y for my taste, but it is very easy to lose track of time while combing a new map or thrashing your way through a dungeon and it is fun to take the (short amount of) time to build your character. Plus there's multiplayer, so fun with a friend!

Posted: July 25, 2015
												Adequate, but not exceptional Diablo-esque.  While the first torchlight was diablo inspired, this is more like diablo 2, done softcore.  There are moments that will give you flashbacks to D2: fetishes in a jungle (no joke), (seemingly) endless deserts and sewers, and a barely-there plot.  Unfortunately, they toned down some of the best things about D2 and left some of the worst.  If you like this genre, it's definitely worth a go.The good:+ There are no bad skills.  Although there are absolutely a few exceptional skills for each class that are much better than the rest, all of the skills will get you through the game just fine.  There are typically two skills that you start with that will take you through the first playthrough.  Then there's a "better" skill that unlocks at 48, which will take you further.  Most of the middle skills are, well, middling.+ Classes are balanced.  I played through with all the classes, Beserker was the surprise favorite (great mobility, great damage, great damage mitigation, great healing, best endgame set, no obvious downside).  The engineer and embermage lag a bit, but not much.  Outlander is solid.  All classes were very viable, even if they played mostly the same (same utility skills in the same spots in the trees).+ Lots of fun little flourishes in some of the art.  Witches appear from a swirl of bats.  Werewolves hang from the rafters and drop down to say hi.+ Enchanting system is much better than T1, skull/eye/gems mimic D2's runes, gambling is actually fun.+ Pacing is mostly good.  A few slow parts, but overall fine.+ Mod scene has produced some very good things.  Not my thing, but it could be yours.+ Lots of achievements.The cons:- Loot.  You'd think this would be a plus; it's not.  Loot progression is fine for the first 20 levels (Act 1) with upgrades reasonably frequent and meaningful, then it hits a wall.  After 20, gear no longer really improves outside of the weapons getting bigger DPS numbers.  Most of the endgame sets don't even bother to have stats - seriously.  My first playthrough, I wore almost the same gear from act 2 till the end.  It's seriously that bad.  The problem is that there's a ton of useless modifiers (armor of all types), and only two or three modifiers that do anything...and those are mostly the +stat options.  Uniques are mostly mediocre; set bonuses are good in a couple cases, but mostly yawn-worthly; even the legendaries aren't that good.- You will only use one or two skills for any character.  Even the engineer - who you'd expect would be busy managing their creations - is just a hold-and-click.- The respec system is terrible.  You can refund your last three skills, except to test out a skill you typically need to put in 5-10 points to see how it behaves at different unlock levels.  The one saving grace is there are multiple respect mods and utilities which correct this without penalty (and you should plan on using one of them because they are essential to having any fun with this game).- Draw distance is far too close.  It's especially bad for ranged characters -- your shots will go much further than the edge of the screen, but won't actually hit anything because those mobs haven't been spawned in.- The luminous area in Act 2 can go eat a bag of.  It's the only area that resets if you die and res to town. (tip: don't res in town, res in the dungeon so you don't have to start over)The rest:* The Acts are not of uniform quality.  Act 2 is awful (endless dessert), Act 3 is quite good (best art, interesting quests), Act 1 is in-between, Act 4 feels tacked on but you can rush through it.* You can just res-get-two-hits-in-die-and-repeat to beat things (aka no hard gear/skill checks).TL;DR: it's no D2, but it's still kinda fun.  Don't expect the world from it and you'll have a good time.  The negative reviews are mostly spot on if you're on the fence.  I'd give it a 8/10 for the first playthrough or for someone new to the genre, 6/10 if you're a genre vet looking for something meaty (and honestly you'd probably be better off with POE).

Posted: February 28, 2016
												Torchlight's actual storyline and most major quests can be completed in ~15-20 hours. However, the extra content that takes more grinding is the real meat of this game. Acquiring end-game loot to make yourself a raidboss is the final destination. My experience with this game is that at first it's quite disorienting, however with more gameplay it gets better, but also becomes very robotic . I do like the graphics and the storyline of the game as well as the variety of different settings and monsters you face. However, if you don't like grinding this game may not be for you. I would recommend this game if it's on sale, but if it were bought for full price I don't think it's worth it.I like the fact that you can Co-op, however in co-op worlds the max amount of players is 4 and whatever you accomplish in that co-op world isn't translated over to your singleplayer, so it's best to keep quests finished in singleplayer first. My impression of the community is that there's a bunch of super dedicated players and keep to themselves a lot and if you're not dedicated you can't break the ice with them. Another awesome feature is that the workshop really brings out a whole new environment for the game. Extra classes, extra abilities,the workshops are a must visit if you want to experience this game fully.Some downsides do include that the combat interface/system isn't explained at first and you're just dropped in a place and you're expected to know how to fight. Maybe a tutorial at first wouldn't hurt. With this being said, the learning curve isn't actually that great if you've played any RPG before. There are 4 basic stats each helping a certain feature and beneficial for certain classes.In summary, I think this game has some great features, the main storyline replayability isn't that high, but the workshops and the extra after the storyline quest grinding will be what you spend most of your time on. I rate this game a good 8/10 for $5.49, maybe lower if it's going for $21.99.

After 142+ hours, I have multiple characters (2 of which are in their first endgame) and alleged plans for another to play with family.  New Game+ still seems like too much content for me to bother with, but it's existence makes this a prime candidate to take if on a deserted island.The cooperative mode is the main draw over the prequel.  There were some sync issues that make me question the viability of playing hardcore mode online.  However, I live in the US and played on Elite difficulty with a guy from Germany without too many deaths I could blame on the network.For those who go overboard micromanaging their equipment stashes like myself, gem availability is also an improvement.  Players are encouraged to use gems immediately because they are plentiful and can no longer be upgraded.  If you don't have any equipment to use a gem then there's not much reason to keep it around.Another, perhaps questionable, improvement is the delayed access to procedurally generated maps.  Although my skills and loot rewards differed, I was initially disappointed at how my characters seemed to be travelling roughly the same environments.  Then I remembered that I never finished the first Torchlight because I focused on an endless supply of random dungeons.  Pushing them to the finale is a suitable reward.  I just wish the map templates weren't so strict and predictable.Overall, Torchlight II is pretty and it plays well.  I suggest placing a mobility skill on the right mouse button if one is available.  (For instance, I have a Berserker with Shadow Burst and an Outlander with Burning Leap.)  I'd also change the hotkey row to something resembling a 3x3 grid, but maybe that's just my own lack of typing skill.

Posted: November 29, 2013
												Torchlight II is a spectical. Sent out as a response to the evergrowing Diablo III, Torchlight II not only improves on its predacessor, but comes to the forefront in the hack and slash adventure. Though, like EVERY game, it is not perfect. Torchlight  II suffers from issues that could have vastly improved the game.When you get into the universe of Torchligh, you are welcomed to a rather beautiful steampunk and "cartoony" world (as much  as I hate describing an art style with that word). When I use my abilities in a blaze of assorted colors, it is wonderful. The art style in this game contrasts a lot hack and slash / dungeon crawlers out there, like Diablo II, Diablo III and Path of Exile. There are four playable classes in the game, all with dynamic and unique abilites. However, there is not much room for experimentation with skill trees, mostly due to the fact that you have to use an exploit to get around this feature. WIth all the  skills usable in this game, it is a damn shame you can't have more freedom. Another feature is the pet system, which is essentially your ♥♥♥♥♥. Put a ton of stuff in his inventory to sell, or send him on a shopping spree! The loot tables in the game are also great. Torchlight II disregards the grindyness of Diablo III, and makes you want to get to the next level, or get new loot! The amount of great stuff that drops is spectacular, and I am so pleased when I defeat a boss to chant, "LOOT! LOOT! LOOT!" Not to mention, the end game is pretty good, with an option to go to the Mapworks, an area in which you can purchase dungeons, and go adventuring through them. OR, you can continue your experience with NG+. However, I did not care whatsoever for the story of Torchlight II. Generic, mythical story with uninteresting characters. Enough said. And honestly, who cares? That is not what you play the game for. Torchlight II is a real spectical - a great change to the formula of Diablo III. Torchlight strays away from making these games a job, and rather a fun game with enough strategy to be challenging. Not only that, but levels are interesting, varied, and creative. Beyond that, Torchlight II is available at $20, where as Diablo III is priced at $60! You will never get a deal like this anywhere else. Did I also mention if you don't like game mechanics, textures, etc, there is a great modding community? That should be enough of a steal for gamers.

Posted: January 3, 2014
												Torchlight II is an entertaining and rewarding Action-RPG for the most part, especially if you are more of a casual player. If you are a hardcore ARPG player however, the game may be a hit or miss for you. The game does what it is meant to do really well and it was well worth the price I payed. If it is on sale I'd recommend picking it up no doubt.As a hardcore player I have both positive and negative opinions on this title:PROS:- Satisfying combat.- Plenty of items and gear.- Friendly to casual players. - Randomly generated areas. - Unique and appealing graphics style.- Great soundtrack and sound effects.- Good Co-Op gameplay.- Save your progress anywhere anytime.- Decent side quests and challenges.- Character classes not locked to certain weapons or gear.- Mod supported.- Plenty of different enemies and areas.CONS:- Only 4 main classes.- Lackluster skill trees.- Unappealing, almost non-existing storyline. - Short completion time (for hardcore players).- Almost no voice acting.If you are experienced make sure to set your difficulty to a high one. I played through the game in two evenings with a friend on Normal which was a mistake from our side. If you are new Normal is fine, if you have kids who wants to play, this game is great for that audience. You can disable blood if that is an issue as well. This is not to be confused with TL2 only being a casual kids game. If you like a good storyline that immerses you further this game does not offer that. Especially when most of the characters doesn't even have voice acting. It was a let down for sure.If you are looking for a complex skillsystem this game does not offer that either. Surely there are skills and combinations that are more complicated but perhaps not from hardcore player's eyes. Since there are just a few skills to choose from, you won't have much choice early on since you unlock the skills as you level up. The skills themselves however can be leveled up individually to grant them greater powers and enhancements. It doesn't really compensate the simplicity and limitations however.If you are looking for a more casual Action-RPG with satisfying combat, exploration, loot, gear and unique look, this game is for you. You don't have to just be a casual gamer to play it but I feel it is aimed more towards this audience. The game does what it does very well if you don't consider the storyline and don't bother too much with a complex skill system. I'd still recommend it to hardcore players if you keep the previous in mind. The game has end-game maps/dungeons that you can play for greater rewards at high levels and you can have it set to a hard difficulty for the challenge as well. Other than that I didn't feel that the replay value was that good.For casual players = 8.5/10For hardcore players = 7.5/10

Posted: November 29, 2013
												Torchlight II is a spectical. Sent out as a response to the evergrowing Diablo III, Torchlight II not only improves on its predacessor, but comes to the forefront in the hack and slash adventure. Though, like EVERY game, it is not perfect. Torchlight  II suffers from issues that could have vastly improved the game.When you get into the universe of Torchligh, you are welcomed to a rather beautiful steampunk and "cartoony" world (as much  as I hate describing an art style with that word). When I use my abilities in a blaze of assorted colors, it is wonderful. The art style in this game contrasts a lot hack and slash / dungeon crawlers out there, like Diablo II, Diablo III and Path of Exile. There are four playable classes in the game, all with dynamic and unique abilites. However, there is not much room for experimentation with skill trees, mostly due to the fact that you have to use an exploit to get around this feature. WIth all the  skills usable in this game, it is a damn shame you can't have more freedom. Another feature is the pet system, which is essentially your ♥♥♥♥♥. Put a ton of stuff in his inventory to sell, or send him on a shopping spree! The loot tables in the game are also great. Torchlight II disregards the grindyness of Diablo III, and makes you want to get to the next level, or get new loot! The amount of great stuff that drops is spectacular, and I am so pleased when I defeat a boss to chant, "LOOT! LOOT! LOOT!" Not to mention, the end game is pretty good, with an option to go to the Mapworks, an area in which you can purchase dungeons, and go adventuring through them. OR, you can continue your experience with NG+. However, I did not care whatsoever for the story of Torchlight II. Generic, mythical story with uninteresting characters. Enough said. And honestly, who cares? That is not what you play the game for. Torchlight II is a real spectical - a great change to the formula of Diablo III. Torchlight strays away from making these games a job, and rather a fun game with enough strategy to be challenging. Not only that, but levels are interesting, varied, and creative. Beyond that, Torchlight II is available at $20, where as Diablo III is priced at $60! You will never get a deal like this anywhere else. Did I also mention if you don't like game mechanics, textures, etc, there is a great modding community? That should be enough of a steal for gamers.

												Torchlight II is a fun little Diablo clone. And when I say "Diablo clone" I really mean it. I came into the game expecting some fresh and interesting gameplay during co-op, but quickly laughed my♥♥♥♥♥off when I discovered just how similar almost everything was. This was made even better by my friend who claims to dislike diablo loving this game. What the hell, dude?Gameplay is generally a slaughterfest, and depending on the difficulty one side or the other will be doing the slaughtering. Posted: November 29, 2013
												Torchlight II is a spectical. Sent out as a response to the evergrowing Diablo III, Torchlight II not only improves on its predacessor, but comes to the forefront in the hack and slash adventure. Though, like EVERY game, it is not perfect. Torchlight  II suffers from issues that could have vastly improved the game.When you get into the universe of Torchligh, you are welcomed to a rather beautiful steampunk and "cartoony" world (as much  as I hate describing an art style with that word). When I use my abilities in a blaze of assorted colors, it is wonderful. The art style in this game contrasts a lot hack and slash / dungeon crawlers out there, like Diablo II, Diablo III and Path of Exile. There are four playable classes in the game, all with dynamic and unique abilites. However, there is not much room for experimentation with skill trees, mostly due to the fact that you have to use an exploit to get around this feature. WIth all the  skills usable in this game, it is a damn shame you can't have more freedom. Another feature is the pet system, which is essentially your ♥♥♥♥♥. Put a ton of stuff in his inventory to sell, or send him on a shopping spree! The loot tables in the game are also great. Torchlight II disregards the grindyness of Diablo III, and makes you want to get to the next level, or get new loot! The amount of great stuff that drops is spectacular, and I am so pleased when I defeat a boss to chant, "LOOT! LOOT! LOOT!" Not to mention, the end game is pretty good, with an option to go to the Mapworks, an area in which you can purchase dungeons, and go adventuring through them. OR, you can continue your experience with NG+. However, I did not care whatsoever for the story of Torchlight II. Generic, mythical story with uninteresting characters. Enough said. And honestly, who cares? That is not what you play the game for. Torchlight II is a real spectical - a great change to the formula of Diablo III. Torchlight strays away from making these games a job, and rather a fun game with enough strategy to be challenging. Not only that, but levels are interesting, varied, and creative. Beyond that, Torchlight II is available at $20, where as Diablo III is priced at $60! You will never get a deal like this anywhere else. Did I also mention if you don't like game mechanics, textures, etc, there is a great modding community? That should be enough of a steal for gamers.

Posted: January 16, 2014
												Like a lot of people, I found myself constantly going back to Diablo 2 and replaying it. Hours of clicking away at monsters, building characters, etc. This managed to re-capture a lot of that fun for me. The game does have a cartoonish art style which may turn off some but definitely doesn't detract from the game. I found the story to be fun and was happy when I completed it. It took me around 30ish hours or so to complete, but I do explore as much as possible and kill as many monsters as possible. The character classes all have 3 different skill trees to build out. I played through with the engineer (support, utility) myself. There is also the berszerker (warrior), outlander (ranger), embermage (caster). If you check out some of the stuff on steam works, you can also get additional classes through mods. End game you get the option to start over via New Game + (ala Chrono Trigger) where the game scales to a level range based on your level. They also have the mapworks option where you purchase maps from a vendor (with gold in game) which can be fun and have various buffs/debuffs to them. On top of that, this game still supports both internet and LAN play which is great. Definitely a solid buy for the price.

												Torchlight 2 is to Torchlight, the same way Diablo 2 was to Diablo. Except without the expansion, it still  shines, where as Diablo 2 required Lord of Destruction to really shine.Now Torchlight 2 literally builds upon Torchlight in pretty much every way. The story continues, with the same three heroes from the last game making obvious cameos, and even useful cameos, which is rare in games today, if you ask me.Torchlight 2 boasts 4 different classes. That's an extra class above the last installment. It even boasts a huge variety of pets, where as Torchlight only had 2. The engineer being your tank or damage dealer, the berserker being a berserker and damage based, your archer style character, and then a mage. All of these classes are well fleshed out and feel correct within the game itself.As for the ggameplay, it's literally the same as the last installment, except they have added the ability to deal damage to multiple creatures based on the weapon type. It all feels correct and works wonderfully. This game is almost perfect. It's only really lacking in developer support. Where's my DLC or added content, Runic?

Posted: January 6
												I've not played a hack and slash rpg for a long time and had felt the itch recently. 34 hours later and I think the itch is scratched for now.Torchlight 2 is a fantastic game if you have fond memories of Diablo 2 and in a lot of way it is a superior game. It is very streamlined and well paced,  the soundtrack is really atmospheric and the skills system was fun for me as a Berserker, having had the most fun in D2 with the Assassin.It is so much more polished, but that is sort of what I think kind of detracts from the game. The economy is so tight, that money was always a concern even in the late game. It makes purchases even later mean much more, but I just didn't like that aspect of the game.The way set items and uniques are distributed also never felt as satisfying as I think they should have. This might be me misremembering how it was in D2, but a lot of uniques were not as good as just some random enchanted items.Lastly this is the first time where I have skipped the story entirely. I got the gist that there's guardians and an alchemist and a netherlord, but from the opening cinematic I was not hooked. The simply shaded cartoony style just didn't click with me at all. I almost feel like a Warcraft 3 in game cinematic might have been better.Despite those things, I recommend this game to fans of the genre and newcomers. I think they did a good job of streamlining the formula, but I kind of missed some of the broken tropes of it's predescessors.

												If you're a fan of Diablo 2, you'll be right at home with this fantastic RPG. Good quests, great inventory structure, pets you can send to town with excess loot and more. Speaking of loot, there is a lot - a LOT of loot. Great effects from spells and some interesting skill trees. Posted: January 25
												Every once in a while, I love to smash everything and everyone in sight - then I turn to a something like Torchlight II. Hack & Slay is the name of the game, and it feels just as satisfying as the rich booty from those battles. The enemies and surroundings are diverse enough, and some bosses look relatively awesome. I say "relatively" because overall, the graphics have not aged well. On the other hand, the music is still excellent. Dialogues are short and do not involve any important decisions or moral dilemmas, which is an advantage because the voice acting is mostly sub-par. Grim Dawn is superior in this regard and managed to create a lot more depth of atmosphere (e.g. the Steampunk setting with fireweapons side by side with swords and maces is more plausible in a post-apocalyptic scenario - Torchlight does not bother with giving you that kind of background). Also, it is four years younger and has better graphics. If in doubt which one you should play, I would prefer Grim Dawn. Nevertheless, Torchlight II is well done, it offers consistently engaging gameplay and character progression as well as several options for you to keep on playing after finishing the main story. The feature that you can use your pet as a connection to town markets is not realistic, but innovative and conveniently saves your hero some annoyingly repetitive errands, which is why I make this honorary mention here. I recommend this game to fans of the genre and give it a 7/10 in this comparison group.

Posted: January 6
												I've not played a hack and slash rpg for a long time and had felt the itch recently. 34 hours later and I think the itch is scratched for now.Torchlight 2 is a fantastic game if you have fond memories of Diablo 2 and in a lot of way it is a superior game. It is very streamlined and well paced,  the soundtrack is really atmospheric and the skills system was fun for me as a Berserker, having had the most fun in D2 with the Assassin.It is so much more polished, but that is sort of what I think kind of detracts from the game. The economy is so tight, that money was always a concern even in the late game. It makes purchases even later mean much more, but I just didn't like that aspect of the game.The way set items and uniques are distributed also never felt as satisfying as I think they should have. This might be me misremembering how it was in D2, but a lot of uniques were not as good as just some random enchanted items.Lastly this is the first time where I have skipped the story entirely. I got the gist that there's guardians and an alchemist and a netherlord, but from the opening cinematic I was not hooked. The simply shaded cartoony style just didn't click with me at all. I almost feel like a Warcraft 3 in game cinematic might have been better.Despite those things, I recommend this game to fans of the genre and newcomers. I think they did a good job of streamlining the formula, but I kind of missed some of the broken tropes of it's predescessors.

Posted: January 16, 2014
												Like a lot of people, I found myself constantly going back to Diablo 2 and replaying it. Hours of clicking away at monsters, building characters, etc. This managed to re-capture a lot of that fun for me. The game does have a cartoonish art style which may turn off some but definitely doesn't detract from the game. I found the story to be fun and was happy when I completed it. It took me around 30ish hours or so to complete, but I do explore as much as possible and kill as many monsters as possible. The character classes all have 3 different skill trees to build out. I played through with the engineer (support, utility) myself. There is also the berszerker (warrior), outlander (ranger), embermage (caster). If you check out some of the stuff on steam works, you can also get additional classes through mods. End game you get the option to start over via New Game + (ala Chrono Trigger) where the game scales to a level range based on your level. They also have the mapworks option where you purchase maps from a vendor (with gold in game) which can be fun and have various buffs/debuffs to them. On top of that, this game still supports both internet and LAN play which is great. Definitely a solid buy for the price.

Posted: April 6, 2014
												One of my first games on steam, and one of the greatest I have played. Although the learning curve can be quite intence (e.g. learning which stats to upgrade for which character, which armor to use, what the heck poison defence does, and so on), the gameplay is quite incredible. The amount of classes offers massive amounts of replay-abiltity, and that isn't including the procedurally generated maps. I originally played as ember-mage, the most difficult class; and found it awesome. Within each class, you can custumize your character for virtually any kind of gameplay, whether that be running into the middle and slashing things, or standing back and having minions do the slashing for you. The art style is appealing although graphic intensive (it made my laptop overheat, but then again that isn't hard to do xD). After my first playthrough, I went as Engineer and tried to hunt achievements; as it turned out I had missed 3 quests! The depth of the game seems to have no end. And I got a good 60+ hrs out of it. I have heard that the special effects are so intence you can't see the monsters. While I could understand that with 10+ people, I did not have this problem, I played it by myself.Also the pets are slightly idiotic with thier spells, but who's judging?Overall+ Good Gameplay  + Good artstyle+ Pet xD+ Quests are well structured and designed+ Achievements are not impossible, but not easy+ Very customizable+ Huge amount of replay-ability- Hard to just pick up and play (tough learning curve)One of the best on Steam 9/10

content:
Posted: June 10, 2014
												For starters, Torchlight 2 is not a bad game.  I played with a group of several friends and completed the game too soon.  It doesn't take very long to finish the game and we ended up by spending the rest of the night talking about what would have made the game much, much better.Thing's such as..More Loot (We hardly found any)More Gold (Almost impossible to find gold)More mobs, (We spent most of the time looking for things to kill)Too long between levels. (We barely hit the cap)Just doesn't feel right.  (Even on a quad core overclocked, the game still lagged like hell)We also thought the game was too realistic for our liking.  There were too many stages in the game that it bought back bad memories for one of our crew.  Most of the time spend looking for mobs was spent consoling my friend on his middle ages hates and nightmares.Too expensive.  I paid $6.20 for it on special, and actually went to download the game of Bay of pirates cause I felt ripped off.We also found the game too Linear.  Not enough choice.THEN AGAIN,The pro's of the game would be it was...Extremely challenging.  We found dying from common mob spawns too often and had to be revived.Just about all of the (hardly non existant) loot was usable.  We hardly found ourselves selling anything from our bags.PLENTY of inventory space! (We think this could be nerfed to balance the game)All classes except the engineer were too powerful and it feels like the engineer is a lonely character with no companions to assist his journey.  Also, Hi's AOE could have been vastly improved as taking on more than 30 or so mobs proved quite challenging.Also, slight suggestion?  Berseker needs to do more crit hits.NOWHERE NEAR, enough potions.The game would probably be best suited to the simulation catagory to be honest.  So there you have it,Torchlight2If your a fan of games like Sims2-3, Sim City Societies - Doom3 - Cruise Ship Simulator, then this probably isn't the gamw for you,however if you love Grand thieft Auto or any racing games for the matter,then spend your money.... You won't be dissapointed.P.S.  Maps were too sparesely populated.Fin!

Posted: August 12, 2015
												I have not played the first Torchlight, here are my thoughtsIt is the single most convenient game that I have ever played.Your pet can pick up items if your own bags are full.. but wait, they can also run back to the shops to sell what's in their bags while you are still adventuring! That is neat!What do you mean the skills 'aren't like skill trees?' Whoah, I can take any skill I want as long as I have the level to take it?! You mean I don't need to take that skill before it to 'un-lock it?' How nice!Why isn't my friend picking up any loot? He has been? What do you mean? Oh.. every player sees their own loot client-side so you don't have to worry about people being greedy?!When you play through a level it will stay that way, meaning you can go through them to look for loot you might've not picked up, and there will be no mobs about. Your portals will also still be there! To refresh everything you can 're-roll' a level by going to Multiplayer and quickly creating a new room and clicking the 're-roll' check .But here are the cons...;Although, Torchlight basically has no storyline (it is there, just not very.. prominent). It's one of those type of games where it has the danger of becoming repetitive depending on what you like to do in games.You may suffer from a serious case of Altitis. I have 7 characters. (Excluding bank mules)Also, it's very annoying that you can't fully re-class and that the class balancing is quite un-even. The ranged classes have little to no survivability and very hard to play with in Hardcore-Elite.Very small bank space. TL2 has so many different armour sets and stats that you might want to keep a few things, but your bank will be full in no time. Bad for hoarders such as myself.There are very strange Multiplayer lag spikes/latency that Runic Games fail to address, believing it must be the player's internet connection, amount other things at fault. Yeah, no.

												Torchlight II gets right to the point. Within a few minutes of starting up you’re dropped into fields of compulsively killable monsters. You’re shown this isn't a game about story: it’s about wholesale, gleeful slaughter. You burn and poison and slash at hostile beasts with sharp weapons until they die and spill gold and gear all over the ground. You scoop it all up, scan stats to see if any discovered treasure can serve as an upgrade, then move on to the next monster pack and repeat. You do this for roughly 30 hours until the final boss falls over, then you start up new game plus and repeat the whole thing.  It may sound like a wearying grind of a dungeon crawl but it’s immensely rewarding.Torchlight II gets right to the point. Within a few minutes of starting up you’re dropped into fields of compulsively killable monsters. You’re shown this isn't a game about story: it’s about wholesale, gleeful slaughter. You burn and poison and slash at hostile beasts with sharp weapons until they die and spill gold and gear all over the ground. You scoop it all up, scan stats to see if any discovered treasure can serve as an upgrade, then move on to the next monster pack and repeat. You do this for roughly 30 hours until the final boss falls over, then you start up new game plus and repeat the whole thing.  It may sound like a wearying grind of a dungeon crawl but it’s immensely rewarding.Like with Diablo, item drops from monster are randomized, so you’re never sure what will fall from the dead. Sometimes it’s a basic pistol you’ll never use, sometimes it’s a rare two-handed sword with high damage and the perfect statistical attachments to complement your play style. Playing is a constant tease, where each magic blast or arrow flurry might reward you with the ideal upgrade, which when equipped inspires confidence, a feeling of ever-growing personal power as you descend into the next dungeon and battle whatever unknown dangers await. It’s an expertly paced cycle of upgrading that never leaves room for rest, as more menacing challenges are never far away, and the promise of greater reward never fades.After the first playthrough is completed there’s still plenty to do, too. A map room unlocks at the very end of the game, where more dungeon runs can be purchased with in-game gold, you can try out additional difficulty settings, roll a hardcore character where death is permanent, and can start up a new game+ mode where you restart the adventure with all character progress intact, letting you level to the cap against more challenging monsters and really get a sense of how powerful your class can become. Who knows what’ll wind up coming out of the modding community that builds up around Torchlight II, but even without community-created content, Runic’s already included plenty of reasons to continue playing for many, many hours. Considering this all costs $20 on Steam, it's a pretty incredible deal.So torchlight II doesn’t do anything radically new, but does everything incredibly well. It fits all the pieces of varied monster behavior, interesting items, excellent skill design and random surprises together into a near-perfect formula, where the action never stops and rewards are never far away. Every level up, skill boost and item replacement flirts with a sense of invulnerability in a world obsessed with killing you, demanding continued play by teasing eventual omnipotence. The story and characters aren’t particularly memorable, but that hardly hurts the strength of Runic’s focused design in what’s one of the finest loot-driven action-RPGs available.

Posted: January 20, 2014
												There are many ARPGs on the market. Like Diablo, Titan Quest, Sacred, Van Helsing or Divine Divinity but how does Torchlight 2 hold up compared to other titles in the genre?Pretty damn well I would say. Torchlight 2 is an excellent game that does many things right and some things wrong. Simply the low price is already an huge incentive to buy the game if you like the genre. The things that make Torchlight 2 so great are the solid and polished gameplay, tons of loot, unique art style and cooperative multiplayer. The game feels really nicely designed and the gameplay is fast and frantic, the interface provides every information that you need in an instant and the controls work like a charm. It's really rewarding to smash through massive amounts of enemies with your skills and check the loot that you obtained. The basic premise works flawless, killing monsters, getting loot and leveling up. The game doesn't look all that great but the artstyle is cohesive and pleasing to the eye, there is a lot of variation in terms of armor, weapons, locations and enemies. Furthermore the multiplayer is really great, playing with some friends is a terrific experience. Each class feels individual and plays differently, personally I don't like them as much but they're more refreshing than the standard classes from other titles. The skill tree isn't that amazing and a lot of skills are just standard rpg stuff, nevertheless there are some really satisfying abilities available. The downside of Torchlight 2 is that it can be quite repetitive, especially in the singleplayer. There are huge maps and dungeons filled with monsters. After a while it's pretty much the same. Each area has their own enemy types that you will be fighting for a long while. The game immediately throws everything at you, so there isn't much to discover or explore. You will usually find some dungeons with typical fetchquests that aren't that interesting. The story is pretty boring and uninteresting, it's all about the gameplay. So there aren't any surprises or epic adventures, the basic formula is to go into a dungeon. Kill everything and then vanquish the final boss.Nevertheless this game absolutely enjoyable and offers a lot of content. Especially the multiplayer which is a blast to play with buddies.. I definitely recommend this game, furthermore there are multiple difficulties available and randomly generated maps.
